docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2--President Arturo Frondizi bowed to military pressure tonight and agreed to reverse the soft stand Argentina took toward Cuba at the foreign  ministers' conference of the Organization of American States.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2--President Arturo Frondizi bowed to military pressure tonight and agreed to reverse the soft stand Argentina took toward Cuba at the foreign ministers' conference of the Organization of American States.
docs.abstract: Frondizi bows to mil leaders, agrees to break with Cuba; has recalled Amb Amoedo

headline.main: Frondizi Bows to Military; Accepts O.A.S. Cuba Stand; Havana Break Demanded Move Called Effective Frondizi Bows to Military Aides; Accepts O.A.S. Policy on Cuba Cuba's Red Link the Bar Delay In Break Seen

docs.snippet: Since the early years of the Republic of Argentina, every Argentine President has had to take the armed forces into account in planning his diplomatic and political moves. President Arturo Frondizi has been no exception.
docs.lead_paragraph: Since the early years of the Republic of Argentina, every Argentine President has had to take the armed forces into account in planning his diplomatic and political moves. President Arturo Frondizi has been no exception.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2-- Argentina's military chiefs, confronting President Frondizi with an ultimatum today, ordered all troops confined to quarters to be ready for any emergency.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- President Kennedy is expected to announce this week-end a ban on all remaining imports from Cuba, which give the Castro Government an income of about $3,000,000 a month.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- President Kennedy is expected to announce this week-end a ban on all remaining imports from Cuba, which give the Castro Government an income of about $3,000,000 a month.
docs.abstract: Expected US ban on all remaining trade with Cuba seen striking Tampa, Fla, cigar indus most severely; '61 Fla imports from Cuba put at $22 million

docs.snippet: A Government victory in a legal drive to collect additional  fees from steamship lines that have chartered its ships has been appealed.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Government victory in a legal drive to collect additional fees from steamship lines that have chartered its ships has been appealed.
docs.abstract: Moore-McCormack Lines appeals Fed Dist Cf Nov ruling authorizing US to recover $592,088 in fees for co charter of 3 US ships, '51-57; co made profit, '51-52, had losses, '53-57; sought to carry forward profits in early yrs to offset later losses
